snippet: The Food and Drug Administration says DMAA, a stimulant used in products like Jack3d, does not qualify as a legal dietary supplement and can cause health problems.
abstract: Food and Drug Administration issues public warning that certain workout-boosters and fat-burning products, with names like Jack3d and OxyElite Pro, are illegal and may present serious health hazards to consumers; cites evidence that dimethylamylamine, active stimulant in products, can potentially cause heart attacks, raised blood pressure, and other issues.

byline.original: By NATASHA SINGER and PETER LATTMAN

lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration says DMAA, a stimulant used in products like Jack3d, does not qualify as a legal dietary supplement and can cause health problems.

headline.seo: F.D.A. Issues Warning on DMAA, a Workout Booster
headline.main: F.D.A. Issues Warning on Workout Supplement
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Issues Warning On Workout Supplement
